}}</ref> One common [[criticism of Windows XP]] and its predecessors is their commonly exploited [[Vulnerability (computing)|security vulnerabilities]] and overall susceptibility to [[malware]], [[computer virus|viruses]] and [[buffer overflow]]s. }}</ref> One common [[criticism of Windows XP]] and its predecessors is their commonly exploited [[Vulnerability (computing)|security vulnerabilities]] and overall susceptibility to [[malware]], [[computer virus|viruses]] and [[buffer overflow]]s. In light of this, Microsoft chairman [[Bill Gates]] announced in early 2002 a company-wide "[[Trustworthy Computing]] initiative" which allegedly aims to incorporate security work into every aspect of software development at the company. Microsoft stated that it prioritized improving the security of Windows XP and [[Windows Server 2003]] above finishing Windows Vista, thus delaying its completion.<ref name="winxpdevpriority">{{cite web
